case_name: Mahant Ram Saroop Das v. State of Bihar

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 343 of 1955 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1954, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judl. Case No. 39 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 343 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1954, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judl. Case No. 39 of 1954.

facts.text: The appellant instituted a writ proceeding under Article 226 of the Constitution in the Patna High Court as Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 39 of 1954 on January 22, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: which the appellant had instituted on an application made under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the circumstances stated below. It was alleged that one Mahatma Mast Ram Hindu saint, owned and possessed considerable properties in the district of Monghyr in the State of Bihar.

facts.text: Mahatma Mast Ram, a Hindu saint, owned and possessed considerable properties in the district of Monghyr in the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that one Mahatma Mast Ram Hindu saint, owned and possessed considerable properties in the district of Monghyr in the State of Bihar. About two hundred years ago, he built a small temple at Salouna in which he installed a deity called Sri Thakur Lakshmi Narainji.

facts.text: Mahatma Mast Ram built a small temple at Salouna about two hundred years ago and installed deity Sri Thakur Lakshmi Narainji there.

anchor.surface_text: About two hundred years ago, he built a small temple at Salouna in which he installed a deity called Sri Thakur Lakshmi Narainji. This temple came to be known as the Salouna asthal. Mast Ramji died near about the year 1802.

facts.text: Mast Ramji died near about the year 1802.

anchor.surface_text: This temple came to be known as the Salouna asthal. Mast Ramji died near about the year 1802. He was succeeded in turn by some of his disciples, one of whom was Mahant Lakshmi Dasji.

facts.text: Mahant Lakshmi Dasji built a new temple in 1916 and removed the deity from the old temple, installing two new deities Sri Ram and Sita.

anchor.surface_text: He built a new temple in 1916 into which he removed the deity from the old temple and installed two new deities, Sri Ram and Sita. in 1919 Mahant Lakshmi Dasji died.

facts.text: Mahant Lakshmi Dasji died in 1919.

anchor.surface_text: in 1919 Mahant Lakshmi Dasji died. He left three disciples, Vishnu Das, Bhagwat Das and Rameshwar Das. A dispute arose among these disciples about succession to the gaddi, which was settled sometime in February 1919.

facts.text: A dispute about succession to the gaddi among Vishnu Das, Bhagwat Das and Rameshwar Das was settled in February 1919, arranging that Vishnu Das succeeds Mahant Lakshmi Das, then Bhagwat Das, then the ablest bairagi of the asthal born of Brahmin parents.

anchor.surface_text: A dispute arose among these disciples about succession to the gaddi, which was settled sometime in February 1919. By that settlement it was arranged that Vishnu Das would succeed Mahant Lakshmi Das as the shebait and would be succeeded by Bhagwat Das, and thereafter the ablest bairagi of the asthal, born of Brahmin parents, would be eligible for appointment as shebait.

facts.text: Bhagwat Das died sometime in 1935.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwat Das died sometime in 1935 and again a dispute arose between one Rameshwar Das, the youngest chela of Mahant Lakshmi Das, and Ram Saroop Das who is the present Mahant and appellant before us.

facts.text: Rameshwar Das filed an application under the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act XIV of 1920 against Mahant Ram Saroop Das for rendering accounts of the usufruct of the asthal.

anchor.surface_text: and again a dispute arose between one Rameshwar Das, the youngest chela of Mahant Lakshmi Das, and Ram Saroop Das who is the present Mahant and appellant before us. Rameshwar Das, it appears, filed an application under the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act XIV of 1920 for a direction upon Mahant Ram Saroop Das to render an account of the usufruct of the asthal.

facts.text: Mahant Ram Saroop Das contested the application by Rameshwar Das stating that the properties of Salouna asthal do not constitute a public trust under the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act XIV of 1920.

anchor.surface_text: This application was contested by Mahant Ram Saroop Das, who said that the properties appertaining to the Salouna asthal did not constitute a public trust within the meaning of the provisions of the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act XIV of 1920 and therefore he was not accountable to any person.

facts.text: Mahant Ram Saroop Das obtained permission under section 5 of the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act 1920 to institute a suit for declaration that Salouna asthal and properties do not constitute a public trust.

anchor.surface_text: Mahant Ram Saroop Das also applied for and obtained permission under s. 5 of the aforesaid Act to institute a suit for a declaration that the Salouna asthal and the properties thereof did not constitute a public trust.

facts.text: The suit by Mahant Ram Saroop Das was dismissed by the Subordinate Judge of Monghyr.

anchor.surface_text: Such a suit was brought in the court of the Subordinate Judge of Monghyr who, however, dismissed the suit. Then, there was an appeal to the High Court of Patna

facts.text: Patna High Court in First Appeal No. 10 of 1941 by judgment dated March 5, 1943 declared that Salouna asthal and properties do not constitute a public trust under Charitable and Religious Trusts Act 1920.

anchor.surface_text: Then, there was an appeal to the High Court of Patna and by the judgment and decree passed in First Appeal No. 10 of 1941 dated March 5, 1943, the High Court gave a declaration to the effect that the Salouna asthal and the properties appertaining thereto did not constitute a public trust within the meaning of the provisions of the Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, XIV of 1920.

facts.text: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar Act I of 1951) received President's assent on February 21, 1951 and came into force on August 15, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Some eight years later, the Bihar Hindu Religious Trust Act, 1950 (Bihar I of 1951), hereinafter referred to as the Act, was passed by the Bihar Legislature and received the Presidents assent on February 21, 1951. It came into force on August 15, 1951.

facts.text: Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts was constituted under the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts one of the respondents before us was constituted under this Act to discharge in regard to religious trusts other than Jain religious trusts the functions assigned to it under the several provisions of the Act.

facts.text: On November 14, 1952, the Board under section 59 of the Act asked the appellant to furnish a return of income and expenditure of the asthal.

anchor.surface_text: On November 14, 1952, this Board, in exercise of the powers conferred on it under s. 59 of the Act, asked the appellant to furnish to the Board a return of the income and expenditure of the asthol.

facts.text: Appellant replied on December 1, 1952 that Salouna asthal is private and Act does not apply, citing High Court judgment in FA 10/1941.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant replied by a letter dated December 1, 1952, that the Salouna asthal was a private institution to which the Act did not apply, and also drew the attention of the Board to the judgment and decree of the High Court in First Appeal No. 10 of 1941.

facts.text: The Board replied that it was not bound by the High Court declaration and asked appellant to obtain declaration under the Act or submit return.

anchor.surface_text: The Board, however, gave a reply to the effect that it was not bound by the declaration made by the High Court and asked the appellant to obtain a declaration in respect of his claim under the provisions of the Act or to submit a return.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed the writ petition on September 13, 1954 holding that the Act applies to private religious trusts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Patna by its judgment complained against dismissed the petition on the main ground that the language of s. 2(1) of the Act, which defined a religious trust for the purposes of the Act, was wide enough to cover within its ambit both private and public trusts recognised by Hindu law to be religious, pious or charitable

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act 1951 applies only to public religious trusts, not private ones.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the definition clause does not include within its ambit private trusts and the Act and its provisions do not apply to such trusts.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts that Salouna asthal is not a public trust based on Patna High Court declaration in First Appeal No. 10 of 1941.

anchor.surface_text: As long as the declaration made by the High Court in First Appeal No. 10 of 1941 stands and in the absence of some evidence to the contrary, the appellant is entitled to say that the Salouna asthal and the properties appertaining thereto do not Constitute a public trust and the Act and its provisions do not apply to it.

anchor.surface_text: The principal point urged before us on behalf of the appellant is one of construction-do the provisions of the Act apply to private religious trusts? The contention of the appellant is that they do not. It is necessary to refer at this stage to some of the relevant provisions of the Act.

holdings.text: the definition clause does not include within its ambit private trusts and the Act and its provisions do not apply to such trusts

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the definition clause does not include within its ambit private trusts and the Act and its provisions do not apply to such trusts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition in s.2(1) read with s.4(5) excluding prior public trust laws, other provisions like ss.29,30,32,48 appropriate only for public trusts, legislative history of regulating only public trusts

holdings.text: As long as the declaration made by the High Court in First Appeal No. 10 of 1941 stands and in the absence of some evidence to the contrary, the appellant is entitled to say that the Salouna asthal and the properties appertaining thereto do not Constitute a public trust and the Act and its provisions do not apply to it

anchor.surface_text: As long as the declaration made by the High Court in First Appeal No. 10 of 1941 stands and in the absence of some evidence to the contrary, the appellant is entitled to say that the Salouna asthal and the properties appertaining thereto do not Constitute a public trust

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous High Court declaration that asthal not public trust under 1920 Act stands without contrary evidence or affidavit from respondents

holdings.text: In view of our finding on the question of construction of the definition clause read with s. 4(5) and other provisions of the Act, we consider it unnecessary to pronounce finally on the contentions... except merely to state that a serious question of the constitutional validity of several provisions of the Act would have undoubtedly arisen if the Act were held to apply to private trusts as well

anchor.surface_text: In view of our finding on the question of construction of the definition clause read with s. 4(5) and other provisions of the Act, we consider it unnecessary to pronounce finally on the contentions referred to in the preceding paragraph,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to decide constitutional challenge under Art.19(1)(f) as Act held inapplicable to private trusts; obiter note on serious validity issue if applicable

holdings.text: We would accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 13, 1954, and direct the issue of an appropriate writ quashing the order of the respondent Board calling upon the appellant to file a statement of income and expenditure with regard to the properties of the Salouna asthal and also prohibiting the respondents from interfering with the rights of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 13, 1954, and direct the issue of an appropriate writ quashing the order of the respondent Board calling upon the appellant to file a statement of income and expenditure

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequent to holdings that Act inapplicable and asthal not public trust, writ under Art.226 issues quashing Board's s.59 order and prohibiting interference

anchor.surface_text: would number make the trust a private trust see the observations in Nabi Shirazi v. Province of Bengal   1 . The distinction in this respect between English law and Hindu law has been thus stated by Dr. Mukherjea in his Tagore Law Lectures on the Hindu Law of Religious and Charitable Trusts  1952 Edition, pp. 392-396  ,,In English law charitable trusts are synonymous  1   1942  I.L.R. I cal. 211, 228. with public trusts and what is called religious trust is only a form of charitable trust.

precedents.case_name: Nabi Shirazi v Province of Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: The fact that the uncertain and fluctuating body of persons is a section of the public following a particular religious faith or is only a sect of persons of a certain religious persuasion would not make any difference in the matter and would not make the trust a private trust

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 13, 1954, and direct the issue of an appropriate writ quashing the order of the respondent Board calling upon the appellant to file a statement of income and expenditure with regard to the properties of the Salouna asthal

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and order dated September 13, 1954 set aside; appropriate writ issued quashing the respondent Board's order to file return of income and expenditure; respondents prohibited from interfering with appellant's management rights unless Salouna asthal determined to be a public trust

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the definition clause does not include within its ambit private trusts and the Act and its provisions do not apply to such trusts.

We would accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 13, 1954, and direct the issue of an appropriate writ quashing the order of the respondent Board calling upon the appellant to file a statement of income and expenditure with regard to the properties of the Salouna asthal

anchor.surface_text: In view of our finding on the question of construction of the definition clause read with s. 4(5) and other provisions of the Act, we consider it unnecessary to pronounce finally on the contentions referred to in the preceding paragraph,

We would accordingly allow this appeal, set aside the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 13, 1954, and direct the issue of an appropriate writ quashing the order of the respondent Board calling upon the appellant to file a statement of income and expenditure with regard to the properties of the Salouna asthal
